entry.title: SAP S/4HANA for Group Reporting - Using Automatic Posting Rules for Consolidation of Investments
entry.content:
Introduction

Automating postings in SAP S/4HANA Group Reporting dramatically reduces manual effort and increases accuracy in financial consolidation. With release 2508.3, you can define posting rules specifically for consolidation groups and automate group-level postings such as the consolidation of investments.

 

What's New for Consolidation Group Postings

Automatic posting rules (you can find more details in this introduction blog) for consolidation group postings now include the following features:

  • Group Structure Filters to select the units based on their assignment in the group structure.
  • Field assignment for Investee Unit to maintain investor-investee relationships in postings.
  • An enhanced log with a new tab to display the log items per investee unit and a quick link to display group structure assignment details.

 

Scenarios

Here are some typical examples of group postings that you can automate for the consolidation of investments:

  • First consolidation: elimination of investments, capital, retained earnings, other comprehensive income, and calculation of non-controlling interests (NCI)
  • Subsequent consolidation: NCI calculation for net income and other comprehensive income
  • Acquisitions and partial disposal of investments: elimination of changes in investments and adjustments for group share changes
  • Consolidation method changes: from/to purchase / equity method
  • Capital increases / decreases with no group share change
  • Total divestitures

Note: Other automatic postings, such as eliminations or reclassifications that must be posted at the consolidation group level can also be defined.

 

Rule Type: Postings for Consolidation Groups

Posting rules defined with the rule type Postings for Consolidation Groups can only be assigned, via the rule group, to tasks of category 55 - Automatic Postings for Consolidation Groups. These tasks are processed exclusively from the consolidation monitor.

Posting rules of this type include options tailored for group postings, as described below.

 

Defining Group Structure Filters

In a posting rule, a group structure filter selects units (consolidation units, partner units, investee units) based on their assignment in the current consolidation group defined in the Manage Group Structure app.

Example use cases:

  • Select only consolidation units with purchase method
  • Select only partner units with first consolidation in the current period
  • Select only consolidation units that change their method from equity to purchase

You define group structure filters in the Group Structure Filters tab of the Manage Rules for Automatic Postings app.

You define in the group structure filter how to select the units, using:

  • the consolidation method assigned to the unit (for example, parent, purchase, equity). 
  • the assignment stage of the unit for the current period (for example, first consolidation, subsequent consolidation, divestiture), including whether it applies at the beginning or end of the period.
  • the method changes (from/to) that occur for the consolidation unit in the current period, including whether the change happens at the beginning or end of the period.

The selection of consolidation method, assignment stage, and method change are optional.

For instance, you can select units considering only their method and not their assignment stage, or considering only their method change. However, assignment stages can only be selected when a consolidation method is specified.

Note: In addition to delivered consolidation methods (parent, purchase, equity), you can create your own consolidation methods in the self service configuration Define Consolidation Methods to support further scenarios, such as proportional consolidation or units held for sale.

 

Using Group Structure Filters in Posting Rules

In posting rules of the type Postings for Consolidation Groups, you can assign a group structure filter in the source data section to select consolidation units, partner units and investee units.

This filter is optional. If no filter is assigned, the rule selects all units assigned to the consolidation group.

Example:

A rule that eliminates investments during first consolidation might:

  • Filter consolidation units with a group structure filter PP (consolidation methods: parent, purchase), and
  • Filter partner units with a group structure filter PU_FC (consolidation method: purchase; assignment stage: first consolidation).

By combining the selection objects (for example, FS items, subitems) with the group structure filters (for example, consolidation methods, assignment stages, method changes) across consolidation units, partner units, and investee units in the posting rule definitions allows you to precisely target complex scenarios for automation.

 

Organizing Posting Rules

Automating group postings for consolidation of investments typically requires many rules. To keep them manageable:

  • Use nodes in the rule group to organize rules by method (purchase, equity, for example) and then by assignment stage (first consolidation, subsequent consolidation, investments changes, equity changes, divestiture, for example).

  • Adopt a naming convention that reflects method, assignment stage, and FS items to make the log easier to read and to present posting rules in a logical sequence (see the log example at the end of this blog).

 

Defining Posting Rules

When defining posting rules for the consolidation of investments, consider the aspects mentioned below.

Rounding difference

When defining rules that use variables with percentages (for example, group share, non controlling share), minor rounding differences can create imbalances. To clear this imbalance, add an extra posting line to balance the entry (see posting line #4 below).

Investee Unit

The investee unit field is typically inherited from the partner unit for investment FS items and from the consolidation unit for equity FS items.

This inheritance links investor and investee units for entries related to investment and equity changes.

In a first consolidation posting, this linkage allows the log to display source and posting lines from the investor (investment FS items) and investee (equity FS items) together, improving the understanding of the posting. (see the log example at the end of this blog).

It is therefore important, when defining the posting rule, to ensure that the investee unit field is not cleared. In most cases, it inherits its value from the source data, If needed, it can also be assigned directly in the rule from the consolidation or partner unit using the field assignment section with the Value Of option set to Consolidation Unit or Partner Unit.

 

Displaying the Log

The example below shows how the log can help analyze postings for consolidation of investments. It illustrates also the importance of the naming convention for the rules, and the role of the investee unit field. 

(1) The tab Investee Unit is selected so the investee units are displayed and can be selected in the left pane (2).

(2) The investee unit GDI US West is selected in the left pane. The log items for this investee unit are displayed on the right. They include the investment FS items from investors GDI Spain and GDI France, and equity FS items for the investee unit GDI US West.

The log items are grouped by rule.

The first 2 rules (investments and equity for first consolidation with purchase method) are expanded in this example.

(3) The investments in the investor units are eliminated against retained earnings in the investee unit. Since the investor GDI Spain is not held by 100%, non-controlling interests (NCI) are also posted here. 

(4) The equity in the investee unit is eliminated against the retained earnings, non controlling interests are calculated and posted.

(5) The group share % of the investors and investee unit are displayed as a variable.

When the Investee Units tab is selected, you can click the investee unit in the left pane to open its group structure assignment details:

Note: The examples provided in this blog are simplified to illustrate the features. Other configurations are possible.

More Information

  • Rules for Automatic Postings
  • How to Define Group Structure Filters 
  • Blog Introducing New Rules for Automatic Postings

entry.title: BKP: AI-Assisted Input Assistance in the “Manage Customer Returns–Version 2” App
entry.content:
Intro

Creating customer returns efficiently is a critical part of modern sales operations. With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602, we introduce AI-assisted input recommendations in the SAP Fiori app “Manage Customer Returns – Version 2”, designed to make returns order creation faster, more accurate, and more user-friendly. This article walks you through the business context, capabilities, and practical usage of this intelligent input assistance, helping you understand how it supports everyday work in customer returns management.

 

What You’ll Learn

After reading this article, you will understand:

  • The business context behind AI-assisted input recommendations
  • How input assistance works during returns order creation
  • Prerequisites, and tips for successful usage

Business Context: Why Input Assistance Matters

The customer returns solution (Scope Item BKP) allows end users to create returns orders using the Manage Customer Returns – Version 2 app. In real-life scenarios, users often face challenges such as:

  • New users may not yet be familiar with the app and need guidance to create returns orders effectively.
  • Users may be uncertain about the accuracy of certain values, such as the returns process variant.
  • Some users prefer to default specific values, such as logistical follow-up activities, based on the order or return reason.

To address these needs, we provide input assistance through an AI innovation called “AI-assisted input recommendations for returns order creation” .

 

AI-Assisted Input Recommendations: Overview and Benefits

The AI-assisted input recommendations are available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and work directly within the Manage Customer Returns – Version 2 app.

Key Benefits

  • Increased Process Efficiency
    Data entry time is reduced as users can rely on AI-driven suggestions based on historical data.
  • Enhanced Data Accuracy
    The system recommends precise values for fields where users may be unsure, reducing errors.

Core Capabilities

  • Recommendations are shown in real time during returns order creation.
  • Suggestions are based on patterns learned from past returns orders with the same process variants.
  • The AI solution supports easy onboarding with Turnkey AI, provided conditions are met.
  • Input recommendations are automatically available.
  • Recommended values are ranked, and those with a prediction probability above 70% are highlighted.

Input and Output Fields Supported by AI

The AI-assisted input recommendations cover both document header and document item levels. The following shows the user input and related output fields:

How AI Input Assistance Works

Returns Order Header Creation

  1. Start by entering the document type and sales area.
  2. Once you enter the sold-to party, the system begins recommending values for the order reason.
  3. If a value has a prediction probability above 70%, it is highlighted (for example, Standard Return (009)).
  4. When opening the value list, the top recommended values are displayed.
  5. You must accept a highlighted value or choose a different one. If no confirmation is made, the system will prompt you during saving. 

Returns Order Item Creation

  1. Enter the product first. This triggers recommendations for additional fields, such as return reason and logistical follow-up activity.
  2. Recommended values appear in the value list. If none exceed the 70% probability threshold, no value is highlighted.
  3. When a value (for example, Receive into Plant) exceeds the threshold, it is highlighted.
  4. As you accept or enter more fields (such as return reason), the system continues recommending values for subsequent fields. For example, a refund code may be highlighted with a prediction probability of 100%.
  5. If you change a value such as the logistical follow-up activity, related fields may also be recommended. For instance, selecting Ship to Supplier (0005) may trigger a recommendation for the supplier number. 

     

  6. If you do not accept a highlighted recommendation, the system will display a confirmation pop-up later.
  7. Once all necessary fields are accepted, you can successfully save the returns order.

    Prerequisites and Important Tips

    To use AI-assisted input recommendations, the customer returns recommendation machine learning model must be trained, deployed, and activated.

    Training Options

    We provide two approaches:

    1. Auto Training (Turnkey AI)

    Turnkey AI is automatically activated if all the following conditions are met:

    • A Data Attribute Recommendation (DAR) connection is established
    • Minimum data volume requirements are fulfilled:
      • 3,000 eligible items for production systems
      • 1,000 eligible items for quality or test systems

    2. Manual Training

    For detailed steps on manual training or on how to cancel input recommendations, refer to the SAP online help portal:
    AI-Assisted Input Recommendations for Returns Order Creation | SAP Help Portal

    Summary

    AI-assisted input recommendations in Manage Customer Returns – Version 2 app are designed to reduce effort, improve accuracy, and guide both new and experienced users through returns order creation. By learning from historical data and providing real-time suggestions, it helps ensure smoother processes and more confident decision-making in customer returns management.

    As customer return solutions continue to evolve its AI capabilities, features like this represent a practical step toward more intelligent, user-friendly enterprise applications.

entry.title: How To Trigger Inbound Delivery With API in SAP Public Cloud Edition
entry.content:
Public Cloud system API functions correspond to the BAPIs in the on-premise system and are also used as service methods.

When using APIs, an integration process can be designed between the SAP system and a third-party system. If the data is triggered by SAP, the APIs will run via Outbound Services; if data is sent from a third-party system to SAP, Inbound Services will be used.

In order to trigger APIs or use them in integration processes, Communication System, Communication Arrangement, and Communication User are created in the Public Cloud system.

Communication System  

The Communication System can be described as a service name. By accessing the Communication System application, the System ID and System Name are entered, the relevant link is pasted into the Host Name field, and the process is completed by clicking the Save button.

 

Communication Arrangements

A Communication Arrangement is the application name that specifies which APIs will be used in the data-triggering process assigned to the previously created Communication System.

The created Communication System is assigned to a specific communication scenario.

 

Maintain Communication User

A Communication User is created within the existing Communication System and Communication Arrangement and serves as a kind of filter that indicates which user is triggering the service.

After the User Name is created, a password is required. To obtain the password, the Propose Password button is clicked and a proposed password is generated. This password is then used to trigger the relevant API when selecting Try Out on www.api.sap.com

SAP Business Accelator Hub

Afterwards, the Communication User is saved by clicking the Save button, and the API links are accessed. The desired API is then found, and the triggering screen can be reached by clicking the Try Out button.

After that, a specific triggering screen must be prepared in order to use the relevant method. This triggering screen can be considered similar to SE37; the link used when creating the Communication System and the port information are entered, and a display name is assigned for the screen. Additionally, the user name and password obtained while creating the Communication User are entered into the relevant fields.

 

Since the triggering process will be executed based on this API, an inbound delivery document must be created in the system.
The delivery 180000009 has been created in the system. After the delivery is created, the relevant method must be determined. For the inbound delivery, a token number is obtained by entering the delivery number into the parameter field of the GET method located under the Header tab. This token number can be considered as a kind of access key that enables data triggering in the system.

NOTE: When entering the delivery number, it must be written as '180000009'. The quotation marks ' ' must not be omitted.
NOTE: Under the Headers parameter, in order to retrieve a token from the system, “x-csrf-token” must be entered and “fetch” must be written as its value.

After the system is run, it returns a response and provides the token number.

 

After the relevant token number is obtained, when the delivery with status A is triggered using the PostGoodsReceipt method, it changes to status C, as if approval has been completed. While attempting to post the goods receipt using the PostGoodsReceipt method, the token obtained must be entered under the Headers section. In addition, the if-match header is added and an asterisk (*) is entered as its value. The purpose of this symbol is to prevent the system from encountering errors while scanning deliveries. After that, the system is run.

After the system is run, a response is received, and the response code is 200. A 200 response indicates that the goods receipt has been successfully posted in the system.

After the system returns the 200 success message, the delivery status is checked.
If errors such as 401, 403, etc. are received from the system, the delivery should be reviewed and verified. Not every error that occurs after triggering the APIs is explicitly indicated by the system. The delivery may be open and pending, the posting period may be closed, the put-away quantity may be entered incorrectly, and many other scenarios should be considered.

As a result, the successful response received from SAP (HTTP 200) confirms that the API integration was executed correctly and the goods receipt was posted without any technical issues. This demonstrates that the Communication System, Communication Arrangement, and Communication User were configured properly, and that the inbound service flow functions as expected. Any non-technical errors that may occur after this step should therefore be evaluated directly on the business document and system configuration side rather than the API integration itself.

Regards,

entry.title: How to get insights in the data footprint of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition tenant
entry.content:
Introduction

Some companies running their business process on Cloud ERP (also known as SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) experience a growth in the license consumption metric that relates to the HANA memory usage. (See blog https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/understanding-hana-memory-related-license-utilization-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud/ba-p/14112835 for more details on HANA memory related license measurement). In this case you want to determine the reasons for the growth.

Purpose

In this blog, we want to explain where you can find more details on memory usage and identify large memory consumers. Furthermore, we guide you to actions that can be taken to reduce memory usage based on best practices.

Be aware that the effect of the measures taken, e.g. deletion, data archiving, ILM destruction on the license utilization varies based on the license model in your contract.

For some of the potential growth drivers (e.g. change documents), it may not be easy to drill down to the exact business object on which most of the changes are posted. SAP offers a Data Volume Management (DVM) service to support you with a more detailed analysis. Get in touch with your CSM to discuss it if required.

Structure

First, an introduction on how to get an overview on memory consumption is provided, followed by a brief look into how to check the memory required for query processing. The main part will cover how the data footprint can be analyzed and after having identified the main data footprint drivers, possible actions are proposed to reduce the data footprint.

Target audience

This blogpost is targeted at SAP Cloud ERP administrators and technical & functional consultants.

Overview on memory consumption – HANA Memory Analysis app

The best starting point for the analysis is the HANA Memory Analysis app. Here you will see two main consumers: data footprint and ‘processing memory’.

As a rough rule of thumb: in an average system, about half of the required memory is used for storing data (data footprint) and the other half is for database management. (e.g. query processing, free space, caches, …).

The app provides the history of memory usage for the last 14 days and up to a granularity of 10 minutes blocks.

The data footprint is represented by ‘Column Store’, ‘Row Store’ and the Buffer Cache where ‘Row Store’ is usually very small and can be neglected.

The memory required for query processing is included in section ‘DB Management’. But note that this component contains many other HANA internal memory allocators. Its total size is not representative of the query processing memory requirement.

In the above screenshot you can see that the memory limit (the part that is used for license metric CY263) was increased between Sept 24th and Sept 25th. Be aware that the axis on the right side relates to the black line of the memory limit and that this axis differs from the axis on the left side, which is used to display the breakdown of the memory utilization.

As query processing depends on the workload, you may see that memory requirements change over time. In the example below, a non-optimized job scheduled every hour caused peaks driven by an increase in the ‘DB Management’ section.

What can you learn from the app?

  1. Data footprint: you can see how data footprint developed over the last 2 weeks. In case of significant data archiving or deletion activities, you can see the effect there. But be aware that if the cleanup was mostly touching ‘Warm’ or ‘Cold Data’ on the HANA disk, then only a subset of that data was loaded to HANA memory.
  2. We expect the sum of Column Store + Row Store + Buffer cache to be roughly half of the used memory.
  3. It is normal to see volatility in the ‘DB Management’ section’s size, if this matches the expected usage patterns, but in some cases, it may need further investigation. (see next section).

Now, that the HANA Memory Analysis app provided a first idea on the main memory consumers (data footprint (Column Store and Row Store) and processing memory for query execution (DB Management), you will want to drill down in each of those sections to find options to reduce the consumed memory.

Let’s first look into the memory required for query processing. You can find detailed information on the resource consumption of queries in the app SQL Statement Analysis.

Query Processing – check SQL Statement Analysis

Sometimes SQLs on CDS views require a significant amount of memory, e.g. 40 GB per query. In case such a query is executed only rarely, that may not necessarily impact the total allocated memory, but in case the execution is more frequent or several of these queries may run in parallel, then this will lead to an increase of the allocated memory.

The extensibility feature in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition offers the option to define individual CDS views. In some cases, these are not optimally defined and may have quite some appetite for memory.

To check if there are queries with a rather high memory requirement on your tenant, you can use app SQL Statement Analysis.

If you find expensive statements on your own defined CDS views (namespace Y* or Z*) you must investigate further in possible optimizations by checking the blog CDS View Performance Best Practices - SAP Community. You can find your own defined CDS views (or on defined fields) by entering the search pattern Y or Z in the ‘Statement String’ filter. This will also return statements on SAP defined CDS views with custom field extensions as also the custom fields start with Y or Z.

We recommend adding the field ‘Max. Execution Memory Size [Byte]’ as a selection option and select for statements e.g. larger than 20,000,000,000 bytes (20 GB).

The main focus of this blog is on options to analyze and reduce the data footprint. We will now look into Cloud Application Lifecycle Management (CALM) which gives a quite complete, but also technical view on the system footprint and then we briefly will discuss the apps ‘ILM Advisor’ and ‘HANA Table Analysis’. Both apps are accessible via the Administrator business role.

Data footprint

Data footprint - ILM Advisor – View by ILM object

ILM Advisor is an app which maps the largest tables to their related ILM object. ILM stands for Information Lifecycle Management and is the tooling that supports blocking and data archiving. See the dedicated blog on ILM Advisor here: ILM Advisor: "Optimising Memory Usage with ILM Objects - SAP Community.

Some preparation work is required by SAP to integrate an ILM object into ILM Advisor. The current coverage is based on the most often growing tables overall S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition productive tenants. So, the ILM Advisor provides insights only on a subset of your data whereas ‘Top Tables – Table Size’ in Cloud Application Lifecycle Management (CALM, see below), is a is a generic view that does not provide many details but covers the total data footprint.

In case of larger systems, e.g. with a non-analyzed memory portion exceeding 80-100 GB, you can open an incident on component BC-ILM-ADV to provide feedback to SAP so that the situation can be analyzed and the coverage of data in ILM Advisor can be improved over time.

The figures shown in ILM Advisor are based on a size metric which corresponds to the space a table takes on HANA disk. It corresponds to the measurement done for C414. In case HANA Native Storage Extension (NSE) is used, the size in memory may be only about 20% of the size on disk.

To summarize, keep in mind:

  • Business objects that are growing on your tenant might not be displayed. Therefore double-check with app ‘Top Tables – Table Size’ in Cloud Application Lifecycle Management (CALM), see below.
  • The figures displayed may be higher than the actual memory allocation

Data footprint - HANA Table Analysis

The app ‘HANA Table Analysis’ shows technical details about tables in your tenant. Be aware of the limitation that only those tables are displayed that are created by using the extensibility option of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. No ‘standard’ tables, i.e. those that have been defined by SAP and are used for standard business processes, are displayed. Besides tables created on purpose via the extensibility options, also so tables to persist the archive information structures (naming convention ZAIRX*) will show up in this app. Archive information structures are created automatically during the archiving process and allow a fast access to data in an archive file by linking key identifiers of a business object with its storage place in the archive. -This data is used to display the first result list in the Archive Explorer app or to allow an in-app display of archived data.
Conclusion: Assuming, the majority of data footprint is created in SAP’s owned tables, this app is not the first choice when in need of an overview of the data footprint, but can be checked for tracking the size of your own defined tables or the size of archive information structures.

Data footprint – Cloud Application Lifecycle Management (CALM) – View by application component

The metric ‘Top Tables: Table Sizes’ in Health Monitoring of Cloud ALM provides a breakdown by application component. The size figure shown here represents the size in memory, not on HANA disk. It is corresponding to the measurement used for CY500 and CY263. For C414, the measurement considers the disk size and can differ.

As this view is generic, it covers the full data footprint whereas ILM Advisor (see below) only provides details for a subset of your data.

(Side note: Do not mistake the figure displayed in ‘HANA Memory Used’ (first card on the left side) as the figure being relevant for your memory consumption related license measurement for license metric CY263. For further explanations, see the FAQ in the blog ‘Understanding HANA memory related license utilization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition’.)

The ‘Top Tables: Table Sizes’ metric aggregates the size data to the level 2 of the application component hierarchy. There may be subcomponents that are not detailed out in the Cloud ALM view.

You can get a view on the growth history per application component, like in the screenshot below for application component BC-SRV:

This breakdown by application component is only meaningful for you, if you have an idea which business objects or data the application components is related to. FI-GL (Finance – General Ledger) may be self-explaining, but BC-SRV or BC-SEC will probably leave you clueless. So, let’s try to shed some light on it.

The following list contains the level 2 application components with most commonly growing data footprint in typical SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud systems:

In case an application component is showing a considerable high data footprint in your situation and does not show up in the above list, you can

  • Use SAP Joule or your personal favorite AI.
  • Search in SAP for Me with the component name. In SAP for Me you will find related SAP Notes for this component and in the header of a randomly picked Note, the description text of the application component can be seen:

 

  • Check if an ILM object related to the component appears in ILM Advisor. If the application component is larger than 30 GB and this is a component related to business data and there is no relatable ILM object appearing in ILM Advisor, please open an incident on component BC-ILM-ADV for further analysis.
  • SAP’s Foundational Success Plan provides the guidance, content, and empowerment you need to define a Data Volume Management (DVM) roadmap to stabilize system growth and reduce existing database size. Available remote services can be requested via the ‘Get Support’ application in SAP for Me (see SAP Note 1296527)

Conclusion

Before going into details of possible actions to take, let us summarize the steps to take to gain insights regarding the drivers for the HANA memory consumption of your tenant:

  1. Check if there is a concern regarding growing HANA memory consumption and consequently growing license consumption of the HANA memory related license metrics. Check license metrics C414, CY263, CY500 (only one is relevant depending on your contract) in the License Dashboard in SAP for Me.
  2. Check HANA Memory Analysis app to see if memory growth is caused by growth or data footprint or by extensive memory usage by query processing
  3. If query processing could be a reason, check app SQL Statement Analysis. In case of SAP owned statements using regularly more than 30 GB of HANA memory, please open an incident. In case of queries on CDS views defined in customer extensibility, please check the CDS can be defined in a different way.
  4. If data footprint growth looks relevant, identify the business objects with the most significant contribution to the data footprint. Starting point should be ‘Top Tables – Table Size’ app in CALM
  5. After having identified the main business objects to look into, go to the details section and discuss the suggested actions (e.g. deletion or data archiving via Information Lifecycle Management) with the business owners. Be aware that decision making regarding data deletion or archiving may take several months and can involve a period of intensive testing, so that the business owners can check on side-effects.

SAP’s Foundational Success Plan provides the guidance, content, and empowerment you need to define a Data Volume Management (DVM) roadmap to stabilize system growth and reduce existing database size. This may be especially useful for steps 4 and 5. Available remote services can be requested via the ‘Get Support’ application in SAP for Me (SAP Note 1296527)

Options for data reduction – by application component

BC-BMT – Business Workflows

What is this data about?

Business workflows are used to manage the processing of tasks e.g. by sequencing tasks and the assignment of tasks to business users. A commonly used scenario is approval workflows in the purchasing area.

How to identify if you should look into it?

Check app Flexible Workflow Administration to get an overview on the existing workflow instances. Alternatively, you can use app Workflow Administration to see workflows that are currently in an active status. This view will not provide an insight into the total data volume of all existing workflows as it excludes completed workflows. Still, it may be useful to get an idea on the daily processed data.

Options on data reduction

Workflows can be archived with ILM object WORKITEM. Only fully processed workflows in a completed state can be archived.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

Use app Archive Explorer.

BC-DB – Table change protocols

What is this data about?

When defining a table, a decision is made whether all changes of data within this table should be logged and written to a table change protocol. Usually, this logging is only activated in exceptional cases, e.g. to keep track of changes on configuration tables. Using this feature for tables containing transactional data is NOT recommended.

For SAP-owned tables, SAP is responsible for the management of the data created. By default, data is kept forever and only removed in case table logging was switched on by mistake.

By using the extensibility feature of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP customers and partners can define tables via ABAP Development Tool (ADT) and decide about table logging and activate it.

  1. Open ADT (ABAP Development Tools) and navigate to your custom table
  2. Expand the table node in the Project Explorer to access technical settings
  3. Locate the "Log Changes" option in the technical table settings

Unlike change documents, simple table logging requires no additional RAP implementation. The logging is automatically handled once the flag is activated. This approach provides a straightforward method for auditing changes to custom tables in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition without requiring complex development work.

Display of change logs:

Business Configuration Change Logs can be viewed in the context of a SSCUI (Business Configuration -> Manage Your Solution -> Configure Your Solution’ or an IMG Activity (app Implementation Activities). Alternately,

  1. Change logs for the changes made in 'Current Settings' objects (those that are editable in all systems including 'Production') can be viewed via the Business Configuration Local Settings Change Logs app. (Job Template Name: STAB_BC_LOCAL_SETTINGS_LOGS_JTN)
  2. Change logs can be downloaded via the Application Job Generic UI app - 'Business Configuration Change Logs Overview' app (Job Template Name: STAB_BC_LOG_LIST_JTN)

For configurations created by SAP customers or partners, the change logs can be accessed in the Custom Business Configurations app.

How to identify if you should look into it?

As there is no overview of table change logs you may first check if table change logging is active for your own defined tables and if possible deactivate it OR request a Data Volume Management (DVM) service to support with further analysis, but be aware that the ILM destruction actions you can take will only effect the logs on your own defined tables.

Options on data reduction

Avoidance: If you identify that logging of changes is activated on non-business configuration related tables (e.g. transactional data), deactivate the flag.
ILM destruction: For existing table change logs, you can use the ILM destruction object BC_DBLOGS_DESTRUCTION_C.

BC-MID (Middleware) - IDocs

What is this data about?

IDocs can be considered as a data container for asynchronous data exchange via communication scenarios. (see help)

How to identify if you should look into it?

As IDoc data is not covered in ILM Advisor, the only indication is the BC-MID component showing relevant size. Check your activated communication scenarios. Maybe some of them use ‘IDOC interface’ as an application protocol as in this example:

Also check message monitoring (e.g. app Overview Message Monitoring or Message Monitoring for Administrators or Message Monitoring for Integration Experts) to see if data in some interfaces has piled up and is stuck in an error status. Interfaces will only become visible if there is an assignment between recipients and users. See app Assign recipients to Users and SAP Note 3358732 - AIF - How to assign AIF recipients to users?

Options on data reduction

ILM archiving or destruction: Use Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) with object IDOC to either archive the data or schedule an immediate destruction. Be aware that archiving or destruction will only work for IDocs in a final processing status. IDocs in error status are excluded. In case you have found a large number of IDocs in an error status, get in touch with SAP (e.g.  your assigned SAP contact) to find a solution.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

As IDoc data is stored in a clustered form on the HANA database, the Archive Explorer app to display archived data will only display the clustered data, which is hard to interpret.

BC-SEC - Security Audit Log

What is this data about?

The system keeps automatically track of potentially security relevant events, e.g. user logon or password check has failed. It can be accessed via the Display Security Audit Log app.

How to identify if you should look into it?

The related ILM object BC_SAL is displayed in ILM Advisor. The size figure may be bigger than the actual required memory (as explained above)

Options on data reduction

Avoidance: As often a significant number of logs is related to logon activities – especially in systems with high volume API interfaces which cause constant and highly repetitive logon activities, it may be an option to check the API configuration and see if larger packages can be processed causing fewer individual logons.

Archiving or ILM destruction: Security Audit Logs can be archived or destroyed by ILM object BC_SAL. There is a hardcoded minimum residence time of 201 days prior to archiving and a retention time of 720 days prior destruction defined.

Some of the security audit logs are managed by SAP and required for secure cloud operation processes. This subset of security audit logs CANNOT be archived or destroyed by you.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

The app Display Security Audit Log offers a selection by ‘Log Datasource’.

BC-SRV - Basis Services

In many cases, the data assigned to application component BC-SRV is of significant data volume:

  • Change documents
  • Application logs and
  • AIF (Application Interface Framework) data

All 3 objects are covered by ILM Advisor and although the size on disk is displayed, you will still get an idea where the big portion of the BC-SRV data may come from and can take a decision whether first to focus on change documents or on AIF data.

BC-SRV – Change documents

What is this data about?

All changes on business objects are tracked. Depending on the application, not only changes but also insert and delete activities are recorded. Change documents are strongly bundled with the business object.

Change documents are usually displayed in the context of the related business object. Example: Maintain Business Parter app:

Result:

In addition to change documents created within SAP defined business processes, there is also the option to activate change documents on customer- or partner-defined objects. This is possible in the apps Custom Business Objects and Custom Business Objects (New Version). Please also see the documentation on the creation of customer business objects here.

Note: If your custom business object is used for storing large amounts of data that changes frequently, the change document feature might have a negative impact on system performance and cause significant growth.

Regardless of the amount of data, change documents need to be archived regularly using the Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) apps. Otherwise, system performance can be impacted. The generic archiving object CHANGEDOCU can be used to archive change documents independent of the related business object. You can find the change document object of your custom business object on the General Information tab in the Custom Business Objects app. See the user assistance on Information Lifecycle Management for details on the archiving process.

Be aware that change documents related to custom business objects, are not displayed in app Display Change Documents (see SAP Note 3552721).

How to identify if you should look into it?

The Display Change Documents app does not provide an easy to digest overview. If there is too much data selected, the app might also not respond. Furthermore, some changes are recorded only during upgrades and therefore do not happen on a daily basis, so they may not be easy to see if the search period does not exactly match the timeframe they were created.

The ILM Advisor app partially shows the footprint of change documents together with the related business object, e.g. business partner. Keep in mind that the size figure may be bigger than the actual required memory (as explained above).

These are the most commonly growing change documents. The change document object name can be used in app Display Change Documents for selection.

Change document object

Description

Comment

PFCG

Role Maintenance

See screenshots below

SUSR_PROF

Profiles and Authorizations

See screenshots below

CATS_DATA

Time Sheets

For every time sheet entry created in e.g. app ‘My Timesheet’ 2 change documents are created, one for insert and one for an additional update.

BELEG

Accounting Document

Usually archived with related business object with archiving object FI_DOCUMNT.

MATERIAL

Material Master

As master data is hardly archived, use archiving object CHANGEDOCU

APOC_OR_CD

Output Requests

Related to transactional data, e.g. purchase orders, sales orders, billing documents. Will be archived automatically when the related business object is archived.

COND_A

Pricing Conditions

As master data is rarely archived, use archiving object CHANGEDOCU

If none of the listed change document objects match your case, ask your SAP contact person for a Data Volume Management (DVM) service for a deep-dive analysis.

The following screenshots show examples how to display change documents in the business apps.

Change document object PFCG:- app Maintain Business Roles:

With ‘Display changes’ you can navigate to the individual changes:

Change document object SUSR_PROF: app Maintain Business User:

Overview of changes:

Options on data reduction

  • Avoidance: Switch off the creation of change documents on custom business objects. (see screenshot above). This will keep existing change documents but will stop creation of new change documents.
  • Archiving: Use the archiving object of the corresponding business object (for transactional data, e.g. sales order) or use archiving object CHANGEDOCU to archive the change documents independent of the related business object (i.e. for master data, e.g. business partners, suppliers, customers, material).

How can data be accessed after being archived?

Use app Archive Explorer

BC-SRV – Application Interface Framework

What is this data about?

AIF (Application Interface Framework) enables you to monitor inbound and outbound messages from and to your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition tenant. Data growth in the AIF application can be either caused by the administrative data of the messages transferred and by the content of the message itself. AIF supports the transfer of data via various container types, e.g. IDocs (see section IDocs above) or XML containers. So, depending on the setup, mainly the meta-data of the messages (incl. application logs and status updates) causes the data growth or the payload of the message itself stored in an XML container also grows.

How to identify if you should look into it?

Check message monitoring (e.g. app Overview Message Monitoring or Message Monitoring for Administrators or Message Monitoring for Integration Experts) to see if data in some interfaces has piled up and is stuck in an error status. Be aware that interfaces will only become visible if there is an assignment between recipients and users. See app Assign recipients to Users

3358732 - AIF - How to assign AIF recipients to users? - SAP for Me

Options on data reduction

Avoidance: Make sure to only receive and send messages at the intended frequency. Experience shows that sometimes interface processes got activated by mistake and remain active unnoticed, or data is exchanged too often.

Deletion: An automatic housekeeping is executed regularly and deletes messages for which deletion is allowed by configuration. Check if deletion is activated for your most important namespaces / interfaces, if there is no need for data archiving as there is no need to keep the data for a longer timeframe.

Navigation: Business Configuration: Application Area: ‘Application Platform and Infrastructure’ -> Sub Application Area: ‘Process Management and Integration’ -> Message Monitoring -> ‘Configure Interface Version - Deletion Settings’.

Alternatively, you use the ‘Implementation Activities’ app: General Settings -> Further Settings -> Configure Interface Version - Deletion Settings.

In case there is already a default number of days proposed by SAP, this can be overwritten.

Example:

Note: only messages in a completed state will be deleted. In case you face a high number of messages in an error status, please see SAP Note 3434004 for a mass cancellation of error messages. This step will transfer the messages in a ‘deletable’ status.

Archiving or ILM destruction: You can configure ILM object AIF_MES (which relates to archiving object /AIF/MES) and run either direct destruction or data archiving for AIF messages.

Note: as the AIF interface also uses application log during processing inbound or outbound service messages, deletion or archiving of the messages will also remove the related application log entries.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

In general, archived messages can be accessed via app Archive Explorer, but keep in mind that the payload of the messages, in case it was in a binary format, will not be displayed in a readable format.

BC-SRV – Application Logs

What is this data about?

Many actions performed in a business process will create application logs to allow you to keep track of what has happened, e.g. to access the result of an executed job, e.g. dunning run or automatic clearing run.

How to identify if you should look into it?

As there is no app to display application logs from all possible applications, it is difficult to determine which application, or job causes most logs. Application logs are displayed in apps that are specific to the respective application and can only be accessed by users with the respective business role assigned. When searching for ‘application log’ in SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library you will get an impression on how many business processes create application logs.

In case you want to get insights into the dominating application that creates application log volume, request a Data Volume Management (DVM) service through your SAP contact.

Options on data reduction

Avoidance: Some processes cause many error logs when not configured correctly. Adjusting the process will help to reduce the number of created logs.

Deletion: Application logs with an expiration date in the past are deleted automatically. You can check the expiration date by adding the respective column to your app.

List view including expiration date:

Experience shows that in some systems there are many application logs created by revenue recognition processes. See SAP Note 3403377 for the pre-defined expiration dates. There is an option to adjust the expiration dates on request for your individual tenant.

Archiving: There is no data archiving option available. Archiving object BC_SBAL is not active in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Some applications archive or delete the related application logs when the business objects are archived. One example is the Application Interface Framework (AIF), so deleting or archiving AIF messages can also affect the application log data footprint.

CA-CPD – Commercial Project Management

What is this data about?

This is the data of Professional Service Projects; often it is planning data that contributes to the data growth.

How to identify if you should look into it?

Check the number of projects and the lifetime of your projects and the number of plan data per project. This gives the first indication.

Options on data reduction

Avoidance: Make sure that the Project has a relevant end date. End dates that are very far in the future will create more plan data.

Archiving: Use archiving object CPD_SS (engagement project)

How can data be accessed after being archived?

Besides Archive Explorer, there is currently (release 2508) no business user facing app to display archived project data in a business-like and meaningful way.

CA-MDG – Master Data Governance – Data Replication Framework

What is this data about?

The data replication framework is used to exchange data with connected systems. Example: upload of G/L Accounts from SAP S/4HANA to Ariba.

How to identify if you should look into it?

There are two kinds of data that are growing: Replication Status und Replication Logs.

For Replication Logs check app ‘Monitor Replication’.

View on replication logs:

For the replication status check app ‘Display Replication Status’:

This app will only allow you to check the status of a selected business object. You do not get an overview of the business object types, that caused most of the replication status data. So, you can either derive the most relevant interfaces from the ‘Monitor Replication’ app or request a Data Volume Management (DVM) service for an in-depth analysis (see SAP Note 1296527.)

Options on data reduction

Deletion: There are two regularly scheduled housekeeping jobs: SAP_MD_DRF_SERVOUT_LOG_DEL to delete replication logs
and
SAP_MD_DRF_MDGD_CP_DEL to delete change pointers of master data governance.
The default retention time is set to 90 days. You can check or adjust the default in the business configuration in section: Database and Data Management -> DRF Replication -> Configuration for Data Replication Framework > Specify Days after which the Data from DRF is deleted.

Archiving or ILM destruction: Use ILM object DRF_REPSTA to use the ILM destruction option to delete or to archive the replication status data. In many cases, ILM destruction is the recommended option unless you see a necessity to keep this data long term.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

Use Archive Explorer app for display. There is no view of archived data integrated into the Replication Framework apps.

CO-PC – Product Cost Controlling

What is this data about?

Most data in product cost controlling is usually caused by actual costing document information incl. the cost component split data. This data is used in the Management Accounting and Margin Analysis applications.

How to identify if you should look into it?

In case of many goods movements, it is highly likely that correspondingly the number of actual costing documents is significant. You can get an idea on the volume by running an archiving run for material ledger documents for a single period in test mode and check the archive logs for the number of records.
Note: prior to execute archiving the ILM configuration of archiving object FCML4H_DOC is required.

Options on data reduction

Archiving: You can use archiving object FCML4H_DOC. You can archive data up to the period before last. This includes

  • Quantity and value movement data for materials
  • Aggregated data of value movements per material and period
  • Quantity and value movement data with cost component split
  • Aggregated data of value movement data with cost component split

How can data be accessed after being archived?

Use app Archive Explorer to access individual records. Reporting on totals records is still intact after archiving. Archived data are aggregated and will be posted as beginning inventory in the period AFTER the last archived period. Example: after having archived all data up to period 12/2024, then the aggregated values per material will be posted as beginning inventory in period 01/2025. Therefore, inconsistencies in the evaluation are avoided.

FI-GL – General Leger Accounting

What is this data about?

Growth in this application component is driven by accounting document line items and universal journal items.

How to identify if you should look into it?

Check app ILM Advisor for size of ILM object FI_DOCUMNT.

Options on data reduction

Archiving: Use ILM object FI_DOCUMNT. Be aware that there is a hardcoded residence time which prevents archiving of accounting documents created or edited in the last 2 years.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

The individual accounting documents or line items can be displayed in apps

  • Display Document, Display Journal Entries
  • Display G/L Accounts Line Items - For Ledger
  • …

As the balance forward criteria are preserved by data archiving, i.e. the ‘totals’ records are kept, reporting on a totals level, e.g. by period is not affected. E.g the Trial Balance app will return correct results. The main limitation in reporting is that the drill-down to line-item details will no longer work after having archived the accounting documents.

FI-LOC – Statutory Reports

What is this data about?

The component FI-LOC (localization) covers several tables. Usually creating statutory reports contributes most to data growth. reports.

How to identify if you should look into it?

Check the number of reports and tasks in app Run Statutory Reports. This is

Options on data reduction

Deletion of an individual run: Use the ‘Delete’ run option in the ‘Run statutory reports’ app

Mass Deletion: Use option 'Clean up reporting tasks' (see Fiori App Library or User Assistance) in the business configuration. Finance -> Statutory Reporting -> Basic Settings -> Clean Up Reporting Tasks:

Select 'Delete Accepted Tasks', if you want the program to delete the reporting tasks with status 'Completed' or 'Content Accepted by the Government'. Note: The 'Delete Accepted Tasks' option is disabled in the production environment.

Select 'Force Delete', if you want the program to anyway delete the selected reporting tasks. This option allows to ignore errors, if any, in the selected reporting tasks.

Although the clean-up is accessed via the business configuration, it is NOT a setting for an automatically regularly executed deletion report. Instead, it has to be re-triggered manually from time to time (e.g. every month or quarter).

Data archiving: Use archiving object SRF_TASK to move no longer required tasks from the database to archive files.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

Use app Archive Explorer.

FIN-CS – Financial Consolidation

In the FIN-CS (Financial Consolidation) area, there are two sets of data that show growth: Task Logs for Financial Consolidation and Intercompany Matching Journals for Group Reporting.

FIN-CS – Financial Consolidation Task Logs

What is this data about?

Group Reporting allows you to consolidate financial data from various sources. The consolidation process consists of several consolidation tasks. The logs of the tasks are accessible in app ‘Task Logs’.

Entry screen:

Drilldown to log details:

How to identify if you should look into it?

Check app ‘Task Logs’ (see above) or app ‘Consolidation Monitor’.

Options on data reduction

Archiving: Use archiving object FINCS_LOG (Task Logs). You can use the condition fields: dimension, ledger, log date or version to define specific residence and retention times. In the archive write job variant you can select the data to be archived by ledger, version and log date.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

Use app Archive Explorer.

FIN-CS – Intercompany Matching Journals

What is this data about?

Intercompany Matching and Reconciliation (ICMR) is introduced to speed up your intercompany reconciliation process from company close to corporate close. As a built-in solution in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, it matches transactions without any ETL (extract, transform, load) processes and reconciles your financial data in real time.

In a matching run, the system rolls in from the data source the data that meets the filter conditions set in the matching method and data source, matches the data based on your input period and the matching rules, and saves the items and results as ’Matching Journal Entries’. The matched items are grouped into assignments, while the unmatched items are also tagged with the unmatched status.

How to identify if you should look into it?

Check app ‘Manage Matching Documents’ that also shows matched documents marked as deleted. Those matching documents marked as deleted are still in the database. It is suggested that these documents should be deleted physically by using ILM destruction object ICA_JOURNAL_DES. Alternatively, you can check the data in app ‘Display Matching Items’.

Options on data reduction

Deletion: Use ILM object ICA_JOURNAL_DES for data destruction.

Archiving: Use ILM object ICA_JOURNA for data archiving.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

Use app Archive Explorer.

FIN-FSCM-CR – Credit Management

What is this data about?

Often the ‘limit formula step results’ in credit management are the main drivers of data growth in the FIN-FSCM component. There is the option to activate events, e.g. when new information e.g. provided by credit rating agencies is imported; certain values change at a business partner, so that the score and credit limit get automatically re-calculated. These events can trigger a re-calculation of score and credit limit. Depending on the number of business partners in credit management, this can cause a huge growth in the number of step results. Also scheduling the jobs to update the score and credit limit in a high frequency can be the cause of huge data growth.

How to identify if you should look into it?

Use app ‘Manage Credit Accounts’, select a business partner and check for the ‘Score Evaluation Log’.

Drill-down to details to see the scoring evaluation result and the scoring evaluation steps.

Options on data reduction

Deletion: Schedule delete jobs via app ‘Delete Credit Management Data’. Probably the most relevant job should be SAP_FIN_UKM_FORMULA_DELETE_LOGS (Delete Logs for Calculating Scoring and Credit Limits), but you should also revise the scheduling frequency of other jobs mentioned in SAP Note 3548031.

The screenshot shows the parameters for job template SAP_FIN_UKM_FORMULA_DELETE_LOGS. It is recommended to run the job twice: for credit limit logs and for scoring logs.

LE-SHP – Shipping - Collective Processing Log

What is this data about?

Collective processing logs are related to activities in the Quote to Cash business process. These logs track errors in

  • Collective Delivery Processing: Logs errors encountered during mass delivery creation or updates, enabling efficient error resolution
  • Batch Billing Operations: Captures billing-related errors during collective invoice processing to ensure accurate financial postings
  • Mass Sales Document Updates: Records issues during bulk modifications to sales orders, quotations, or contracts

How to identify if you should look into it?

Use ‘My Collective Run Logs’ app to check on existing logs

Options on data reduction

Use ILM destruction object LE_SHP_LOG_DESTRUCTION

MM-IM – Inventory Management - Goods Movements

What is this data about?

Goods receipts and goods issues are tracked as goods movements.

How to identify if you should look into it?

Check app ILM Advisor to see if ILM object MM_MATBEL appears with a significant size. Also, app ‘Goods Movement Analysis’ can provide valuable insights.

Options on data reduction

Data archiving with ILM object MM_MATBEL.

How can data be accessed after being archived?

Use app Archive Explorer.

Good to know: the following stock identifying fields per period are preserved even after archiving, so that this aggregated information per period still exists after archiving and can be used by apps:

  • Batch Number (Stock Identifier)
  • Addl Supplier SID
  • Customer for Special Stock
  • Special Stock Valuation
  • Stock Type
  • Storage Location (Stock Identifier)
  • Supplier for Special Stock
  • Sales Order Number of Valuated Sales Order Stock
  • Sales Order Item of Valuated Sales Order Stock
  • Valuated Sales Order Stock WBS Element
  • Material in Respect of Which Stock is Managed
  • Base Unit of Measure
  • Special Stock Indicator
  • Currency Key
  • Plant
  • Vendor Stock Valuation Indicator
  • Cost Estimate Number - Product Costing
  • Parallel Unit of Measure (Stock Identifier)
  • Period/Year

SD-BF – Pricing conditions

What is this data about?

Pricing conditions can be linked to pricing relevant line items in either the sales or purchasing process. Most commonly, most pricing conditions are related to sales order items or billing document items. Pricing conditions also often exist on purchase order items, but usually they don’t contribute to data volumes as much as the sales-related pricing conditions. Depending on the complexity of the pricing model, the number of conditions per line item varies significantly. Complex pricing models can cause up to 80 pricing records per e.g. sales order line item.

How to identify if you should look into it?

Check app ILM Advisor if ILM objects SD_VBAK (Sales Orders), SD_VBRK (Billing Documents) or MM_EKKO (Purchase Orders) are of significant size. As pricing conditions are archived together with the related business object, the size of the pricing conditions is added to the leading business object.

Besides checking ILM Advisor, you may also talk to the pricing experts in your sales department and ask them to check some example business objects (e.g. sales orders or billing document) for the number of pricing conditions related to them.

Options on data reduction

Archiving: There is no dedicated ILM archiving object for pricing conditions. Instead, pricing conditions are archived with the related business objects. The business objects most commonly tributing most to pricing condition growth are SD_VBAK (Sales Orders) and SD_VBRK (Billing Documents).

How can data be accessed after being archived?

  • Billing Documents: App ‘Display Billing Documents from Archive’
  • Sales Orders: App ‘Display Sales Orders - VA03’
  • Purchase Orders: App ‘Display Purchase Order – Advanced’
